elements.content: The commercial application of lithium–oxygen (Li–O2) batteries has been seriously hindered by their large overpotential and inferior cycling performance caused by the insoluble and insulated traits of the discharge product, Li2O2. Herein, hierarchical hollow NiCo-LDH/MnO2 hybrid nanostructures derived from metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are successfully constructed as cathodes for Li–O2 batteries to fundamentally improve the decomposition kinetics of Li2O2. The hollow NiCo-LDH/MnO2 nanostructures assembled by hollow NiCo-LDH and MnO2 nanosheets possess a highly special surface area, abundant open active sites, and a fast diffusion path for Li+ and oxygen species. As expected, accelerated sluggish oxygen reduction reaction/oxygen evolution reaction kinetics and reduced charge/discharge overpotentials can be obtained. The toroidal Li2O2 assembled by nanoflakes formed on the surface of the cathode can be conducive to form a low-impedance Li2O2/cathode contact interface to achieve the reversible formation and decomposition of Li2O2. The Li–O2 battery based on the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode shows a high charge/discharge specific capacity of 13,380 mA h g–1 at 100 mA g–1 and a continuous cycling stability for 162 cycles at a fixed capacity of 500 mAh g–1 as well as a low overpotential of 0.63 V. Moreover, the application of MOF-derived porous hierarchical nanostructures expands the selection range of electrocatalysts and offers a new idea of structure design for Li–O2 batteries.

Herein, hierarchical hollow NiCo-LDH/MnO2 hybrid nanostructures derived from metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are successfully constructed as cathodes for Li-O2 batteries to fundamentally improve the decomposition kinetics of Li2O2. The hollow NiCo-LDH/MnO2 nanostructures assembled by hollow NiCo-LDH and MnO2 nanosheets possess a highly special surface area, abundant open active sites, and a fast diffusion path for Li+ and oxygen species. As expected, accelerated sluggish oxygen reduction reaction/oxygen evolution reaction kinetics and reduced charge/discharge overpotentials can be obtained. The toroidal Li2O2 assembled by nanoflakes formed on the surface of the cathode can be conducive to form a low-impedance Li2O2/cathode contact interface to achieve the reversible formation and decomposition of Li2O2. The Li-O2 battery based on the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode shows a high charge/discharge specific capacity of 13,380 mA h g-1 at 100 mA g-1 and a continuous cycling stability for 162 cycles at a fixed capacity of 500 mAh g-1 as well as a low overpotential of 0.63 V. Moreover, the application of MOF-derived porous hierarchical nanostructures expands the selection range of electrocatalysts and offers a new idea of structure design for Li-O2 batteries.

elements.content: Rechargeable lithium–oxygen (Li–O2) batteries (LOBs) have attracted much attention because of their super higher theoretical energy density (3505 W h kg–1) than most of the advanced lithium-ion batteries. Thus, this outstanding advantage makes LOBs as a potential candidate for high-performance electric vehicles and energy storage devices. Accompanied by the generation and decomposition of the discharge product Li2O2 on the cathode, the battery reaction process includes the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in two steps, which greatly determine the electrochemical performance of the LOBs. During the ORR process, a large amount of Li2O2 was formed and deposited on the surface of the electrode, which may inevitably hinder the transport of ions and gas, as well as increase the impedance of the interface charger transfer, causing poor battery capacity and charge transport capability. In the process of OER, higher overpotential and sluggish OER kinetics are triggered by the knotty Li2O2 with insulated and insoluble features. These challenges make LOBs far from practical applications.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Rechargeable lithium-oxygen (Li-O2) batteries (LOBs) have attracted much attention because of their super higher theoretical energy density (3505 W h kg-1) than most of the advanced lithium-ion batteries. Thus, this outstanding advantage makes LOBs as a potential candidate for high-performance electric vehicles and energy storage devices. Accompanied by the generation and decomposition of the discharge product Li2O2 on the cathode, the battery reaction process includes the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in two steps, which greatly determine the electrochemical performance of the LOBs. During the ORR process, a large amount of Li2O2 was formed and deposited on the surface of the electrode, which may inevitably hinder the transport of ions and gas, as well as increase the impedance of the interface charger transfer, causing poor battery capacity and charge transport capability. In the process of OER, higher overpotential and sluggish OER kinetics are triggered by the knotty Li2O2 with insulated and insoluble features. These challenges make LOBs far from practical applications.

elements.content: Much attention has been paid on the reaction mechanism associated with Li2O2 of LOBs for improving the electrochemical performance of this promising system, and it has been well established that the generation of a large-sized Li2O2 toroid, disc, or sphere based on the solvation-mediated pathway ORR mechanism contributes to a high discharge capacity output but at the cost of a large charge overpotential in the process of OER. It is believed that thin films or Li2O2 nanoflakes formed because of the surface-adsorption pathway ORR mechanism were distributed on the cathode surface, which can afford much smaller charge transfer impedance and low overpotential, but the active sites on the electrode are passivated easily thus causing a low discharge capacity. Therefore, a suitable Li2O2 structure can better meet the needs of LOBs and enhance the electrochemical performance.

It is believed that thin films or Li2O2 nanoflakes formed because of the surface-adsorption pathway ORR mechanism were distributed on the cathode surface, which can afford much smaller charge transfer impedance and low overpotential, but the active sites on the electrode are passivated easily thus causing a low discharge capacity. Therefore, a suitable Li2O2 structure can better meet the needs of LOBs and enhance the electrochemical performance.

elements.content: Improving the catalytic performance of the electrodes plays a key role in obtaining enhanced electrochemical performance of LOBs. The catalytic activities on the cathode are investigated in various catalysts, such as metal oxides, metal nitrides, metal sulfides, and so forth. It is shown that the microstructure characteristics are the most important factor for effectively regulating the adsorption energy of superoxide radicals to control the deposition behavior and morphology of Li2O2. It is noted that the porous structure with a high specific surface area and a large number of mesopores is more beneficial for the electrochemical performance of LOBs. A high specific surface area can provide more electrochemical active sites to accelerate the generation and decomposition of Li2O2 to achieve a high specific capacity. The presence of mesopores is in favor of electrolyte and ion diffusion as well as the formation of Li2O2 by providing a three-phase region of the electrochemical reaction (solid–liquid–gas). The layered double hydroxides (LDHs) containing earth abundant transition metals display excellent OER properties, showing a variety of potential applications in the field of water splitting, capacitors, Zn–air batteries, and so forth. It is shown that two-dimensional (2D) channels of LDHs with largely accessible surfaces can provide fast reaction kinetics. While the metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are a class of porous materials composed of metal ions and organic ligands. The advantages of a controllable structure, a large specific surface area, and an ordered porous channel make MOFs and their derivatives promising for application in LOBs. MOFs can be sacrificial templates and metal precursors to construct various complex structures and form a variety of metal/carbon-based materials, such as metal oxides, sulfides, phosphides, LDHs, and so on. In particular, the MOF-derived three-dimensional hollow framework combined with LDHs should be an ideal structure for volume alleviation and alleviating nanoparticle agglomeration, and for achieving shortened mass transfer channels as well as more electrochemically open active sites. δ-MnO2 with a 2D lamellar structure has been investigated as it is a prominent candidate for ORR catalysts because of its low cost, environmental friendliness, and highly catalytic activity. In addition, previous report shows that δ-MnO2 attacked by reactive Li2O2 and LiO2 also remains relatively stable.

elements.content: Herein, an efficient strategy to construct novel hollow NiCo-LDH/MnO2 hierarchical nanostructures as cathodes for LOBs is developed. Specifically, the hollow NiCo-LDH nanocages are formed by ZIF-67 as the self-template, and then the ultrathin MnO2 nanosheets are grown on the NiCo-LDH nanocages. The LOBs based on NiCo-LDH/MnO2 nanostructures display a lower overpotential (0.63 V) and a higher capacity of 13380 mA h g –1 at a current density of 100mA g–1 as well as excellent cycling stability (163 cycles at 100 mA g –1) because of the synergistic effect of NiCo-LDH and MnO2. NiCo-LDH/MnO2 nanocages modulate the Li2O2 growth mechanisms of the surface-adsorption pathway and the solvation-mediated pathway to induce the formation of unique porous toroidal Li2O2 assembled by densified nanoflakes with poor crystallinity. This unique structure offers a large specific surface area and accelerates the complete decomposition of Li2O2 during the OER.

NiCo-LDH/MnO2 nanocages modulate the Li2O2 growth mechanisms of the surface-adsorption pathway and the solvation-mediated pathway to induce the formation of unique porous toroidal Li2O2 assembled by densified nanoflakes with poor crystallinity. This unique structure offers a large specific surface area and accelerates the complete decomposition of Li2O2 during the OER.

elements.content: The controllable synthesis process of NiCo-LDH/MnO2 hierarchical nanostructures with a porous hollow structure is illustrated in . First, the ZIF-67 precursor is prepared according to a reported process. Then, the as-prepared ZIF-67 is used as the self-template to react with the nickel nitrate solution to produce the hollow NiCo-LDH porous nanostructures at 60 °C. During this process, protons are generated by the hydrolysis process to break the coordinate bonding between Co2+ and 2-methylimidazole, forming the hollow NiCo-LDH nanocages. Finally, the MnO2 nanosheets are homogeneously grown on NiCo-LDH nanocages through a facile hydrothermal reaction to fabricate porous NiCo-LDH/MnO2 hierarchical nanostructures. For a comparison, NiCo-LDH nanocages and MnO2 nanosheets are also prepared, respectively. The morphologies of ZIF-67, NiCo-LDH, and NiCo-LDH/MnO2 are observed using a field emission scanning electron microscope ( and S1). As shown in Figure S1, ZIF-67 presents a rhombic dodecahedron structure with a smooth surface. It can be seen that the hollow NiCo-LDH nanocages are composed of ordered ultrathin flakes with neat edges and still maintain the same shape as ZIF-67 (a,b). As revealed in c,d, the NiCo-LDH matrix is covered by MnO2 nanosheets with a uncial shape and a rougher surface. The robust framework provides a large surface area and increases the open diffusion channels of Li+ and O2 for improved mass transfer kinetics. In addition, the active sites on nanosheets are fully exposed to improve the catalytic activity of NiCo-LDH/MnO2, which plays an important role in increasing the discharge capacity and reducing the ORR/OER voltage gap for LOBs.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure and Morphology Characterization

The controllable synthesis process of NiCo-LDH/MnO2 hierarchical nanostructures with a porous hollow structure is illustrated in . First, the ZIF-67 precursor is prepared according to a reported process. Then, the as-prepared ZIF-67 is used as the self-template to react with the nickel nitrate solution to produce the hollow NiCo-LDH porous nanostructures at 60 °C. During this process, protons are generated by the hydrolysis process to break the coordinate bonding between Co2+ and 2-methylimidazole, forming the hollow NiCo-LDH nanocages. Finally, the MnO2 nanosheets are homogeneously grown on NiCo-LDH nanocages through a facile hydrothermal reaction to fabricate porous NiCo-LDH/MnO2 hierarchical nanostructures. For a comparison, NiCo-LDH nanocages and MnO2 nanosheets are also prepared, respectively. The morphologies of ZIF-67, NiCo-LDH, and NiCo-LDH/MnO2 are observed using a field emission scanning electron microscope ( and S1). As shown in Figure S1, ZIF-67 presents a rhombic dodecahedron structure with a smooth surface. It can be seen that the hollow NiCo-LDH nanocages are composed of ordered ultrathin flakes with neat edges and still maintain the same shape as ZIF-67 (a,b). As revealed in c,d, the NiCo-LDH matrix is covered by MnO2 nanosheets with a uncial shape and a rougher surface. The robust framework provides a large surface area and increases the open diffusion channels of Li+ and O2 for improved mass transfer kinetics. In addition, the active sites on nanosheets are fully exposed to improve the catalytic activity of NiCo-LDH/MnO2, which plays an important role in increasing the discharge capacity and reducing the ORR/OER voltage gap for LOBs.

elements.content: The microstructures of NiCo-LDH, MnO2, NiCo-LDH/MnO2 samples are further analyzed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-resolution TEM (HRTEM), and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern, as shown in and S1. The TEM image of the ZIF-67 derived NiCo-LDH sample in a shows a typical hollow structure composed of orderly aligned sheets, and the shape is well maintained as that of the ZIF-67 template. The porous structure is advantageous to shorten the diffusion distance of the electrolyte and ions, meanwhile a large number of channels between the sheets can promote mass transfer to keep efficient generation and decomposition of the Li2O2. The diffraction rings of the SAED pattern in b reveal the (012) and (110) planes of NiCo-LDH. MnO2 presents an irregular wrinkle ultrathin nanosheet structure (Figure S2). For the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 porous hierarchical nanostructures, as shown in c,d, the thickness of the shell significantly increases because of the combination of the MnO2 nanosheets. The HRTEM image (e) evidently uncovers the lattice d-spacings of 0.26 and 0.21 nm, matching well with the (012) plane of NiCo-LDH and the (015) plane of MnO2, respectively. As shown in f, the diffraction rings of the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 sample in the SAED image can be indexed to the (012) and (110) planes of NiCo-LDH and the (015) and (021) planes of MnO2, respectively. g–j indicates that the Ni, Co, and Mn elements are evenly distributed in the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 hollow hierarchical composite nanostructures.

elements.content: The crystal structures of the NiCo-LDH, MnO2, and NiCo-LDH/MnO2 samples are determined using the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns. From a, the broad diffraction peaks at 11.7, 23.7, 34.2, and 60.1° can be assigned to the (003), (006), (012), and (110) planes indexed to the Ni­(OH)2 phase (JCPDS no. 38-0715). In addition, the diffraction peaks located at 12.5, 25.0, 36.8, and 65.5° are attributed to the (003), (006), (101), and (110) planes of δ-MnO2 (JCPDS no. 86-0666), respectively. The composition and chemical bonding states of the hollow NiCo-LDH/MnO2 nanocages are further confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The survey scan of the XPS spectrum (Figure S3) shows the presence of the peaks of Co 2p, Ni 2p, Mn 2p, Mn 3s, Mn 3p, and O1s. For the Co 2p spectrum, the peaks at 795.9 and 780.7 eV correspond to 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of Co2+, and the peaks at 790.4 and 774.5 eV are correspond to Co3+. The high-resolution XPS Ni 2p spectrum (c) also can be fitted into four peaks, which correspond to the Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 of Ni2+ (855.5 and 873.1 eV) as well as the satellite feature (874.3 and 856.6 eV). In the Mn 2p spectrum, the Mn 2p3/2 (642.1 eV) and Mn 2p1/2 (653.8 eV) peaks can be accounted for Mn4+. Additionally, the O 1s peak in e can be deconvoluted into two peaks. The peak at 529.8 eV is assigned to the Mn–O functional group and the distinct peak at 531.1 eV is associated with the hydroxide groups, suggesting the formation of NiCo-LDH. According to the elemental contents measured by XPS (Table S2), the weight ratio of MnO2 is about 36% in the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 composite.

elements.content: As shown in f and S5, the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms of NiCo-LDH and NiCo-LDH/MnO2 display the characteristics of the type-IV isotherm, indicating that the presence of abundant mesopores in the samples. The pore size distribution of the NiCo-LDH and NiCo-LDH/MnO2 samples is found to be mainly on the mesoscale. It shows a large specific surface area of NiCo-LDH/MnO2 (217.1 m2 g–1) calculated using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method from isotherms, similar to that of NiCo-LDH (218.9 m2 g–1). This porous structure is conducive to gas diffusion and ion transportation as well as the accelerating battery reaction rate.

elements.content: The electrochemical performances of NiCo-LDH, MnO2, and NiCo-LDH/MnO2 electrodes are comparatively investigated. The electrochemical measurement results are calculated on the basis of the total weight of cathode catalysts (NiCo-LDH or MnO2 or NiCo-LDH/MnO2) and Super P. a displays the cyclic voltammogram (CV) plots of the three electrodes at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s–1 within the voltage range of 2.0–4.5 V. The CV plot of the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 hybrid catalyst electrode exhibits a single cathodic peak at around 2.44 V, which is ascribed to the oxygen reduction (O2 + 2Li+ + 2e– → Li2O2), while the two oxidation peaks located at 3.41 and 4.36 V are ascribed to the stepwise delithiation and the bulk oxidation process of Li2O2 (Li2O2 → O2 + 2Li+ + 2e–), which are higher than those of NiCo-LDH and MnO2 monophase catalyst electrodes. Compared with two monophase catalysts, the hybrid catalyst delivers a higher ORR onset potential and a lower OER onset potential, revealing the higher ORR and OER catalytic activity. In addition, the higher ORR and OER peak current and integrated area indicate that there are more Li2O2 generation/decomposition.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Performance of Electrocatalysts in LOBs

The electrochemical performances of NiCo-LDH, MnO2, and NiCo-LDH/MnO2 electrodes are comparatively investigated. The electrochemical measurement results are calculated on the basis of the total weight of cathode catalysts (NiCo-LDH or MnO2 or NiCo-LDH/MnO2) and Super P. a displays the cyclic voltammogram (CV) plots of the three electrodes at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s-1 within the voltage range of 2.0-4.5 V. The CV plot of the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 hybrid catalyst electrode exhibits a single cathodic peak at around 2.44 V, which is ascribed to the oxygen reduction (O2 + 2Li+ + 2e- → Li2O2), while the two oxidation peaks located at 3.41 and 4.36 V are ascribed to the stepwise delithiation and the bulk oxidation process of Li2O2 (Li2O2 → O2 + 2Li+ + 2e-), which are higher than those of NiCo-LDH and MnO2 monophase catalyst electrodes. Compared with two monophase catalysts, the hybrid catalyst delivers a higher ORR onset potential and a lower OER onset potential, revealing the higher ORR and OER catalytic activity. In addition, the higher ORR and OER peak current and integrated area indicate that there are more Li2O2 generation/decomposition.

elements.content: b depicts three galvanostatic discharge/charge profiles in the voltage window of 2.0–4.5 V versus Li+/Li with NiCo-LDH, MnO2, and NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathodes at a current density of 100 mA g–1. By comparison, the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode exhibits a high discharge capacity (13380 mA h g–1) with the reversible ORR/OER process, while the NiCo-LDH and MnO2 electrodes can only exhibit capacities of 5380 and 9360 mA h g–1. It should be noted that the discharge capacities are mainly contributed by ORR (Figure S6). In addition, the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 catalyst also plays a significant role in reducing the polarization of LOBs. The NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode exhibits a flat discharge plateau of 2.66 V and a charge midcapacity potential (defined as the voltage at half capacity) of 4.0 V with the lower polarization (approximately 0.30 and 1.04 V during discharge and charge). However, the overpotential of NiCo-LDH and MnO2 is 1.47 and 1.59 V, respectively, marking the generation and decomposition of Li2O2 more difficult, and the side reactions are exacerbated during the discharge/charge process for monophase catalyst cathodes. Therefore, NiCo-LDH/MnO2 with enhanced OER and ORR catalytic activity can effectively improve the electrochemical performance of LOBs.

elements.content: c shows the discharge/charge curves of NiCo-LDH, MnO2, and NiCo-LDH/MnO2 electrodes at various current densities. The ORR/OER overpotentials of these three electrodes increase with the increasing of current density to different degrees. The increment of the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 electrode is the smallest. The overpotential of NiCo-LDH/MnO2 is 1.44 V at 400 mA g–1 and 1.60 V at 800 mA g–1. Moreover, the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 electrode still maintains a high capacity of about 9099 mA h g–1 at a current density of 800 mA g–1, indicating its good capacity retention performance. However, when the current density recovers to 200 mA g–1, an approximate original state can still be restored. Furthermore, the capacity retention of the battery with the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 electrode is also improved (e). For instance, the discharge capacity retention of NiCo-LDH/MnO2 is 78.8% at 400 mA g–1, while the NiCo-LDH and MnO2 sample reserves only 72.9 and 66.3%. When the current density increases to 800 mA g–1, the capacity retention of the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 electrode maintains at 68.0%, and the values of the NiCo-LDH and MnO2 electrodes, respectively, decrease to 52.3 and 38.8% yet. The improvements of the capacity and rate capability should be ascribed to the synergistic effect of NiCo-LDH and MnO2.

elements.content: By the way, the reliable rate capability of the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 electrode is measured at different current densities (200, 400, 800, and 1000 mA g–1) with a cut-off capacity of 1000 mA h g–1. As shown in f, the terminal discharge potential gradually decreases from 2.69 to 2.67 V with the increasing of current density from 200 to 1000 mA g–1. In the meantime, the charging terminal potential smoothly goes up from 3.91 to 4.11 V. Nevertheless, when the current density returns to 200 mA g–1 again, the overpotential is restored to the initial state, implying that this battery exhibits good reversibility. On the contrary (Figure S7), those discharge/charge overpotentials of the two monophase electrodes increase rapidly with the increase of current density. Thus, the hybrid catalyst cathode exhibits better electrochemical stability.

elements.content: The cycling stability of LOBs based on three cathodes is measured at a current density of 100 mA g–1 and a cutoff capacity of 500 mA h g–1 (). The NiCo-LDH/MnO2-based electrode battery displays a better cycling performance than others. The NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode shows a reduced overpotential (0.21/0.42 V) for both discharge and charge in comparison with NiCo-LDH (0.38 V/0.46 V) and MnO2 (0.29 V/0.76 V) cathodes at the first cycle (a), demonstrating that the synergistic effect of NiCo-LDH and MnO2 can enhance the formation and decomposition kinetics of Li2O2. As illustrated in d, the LOB based on the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode exhibits a longer cycle life of 162 cycles before the terminal voltage drops below 2 V, while NiCo-LDH and MnO2 only work for 98 cycles and 31 cycles, respectively. The terminal discharge/charge voltages maintain relatively stable states up to 130 cycles for the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 electrode. The charge overpotentials of NiCo-LDH (c) and MnO2 (Figure S8) electrodes increase continuously to 4.5 V during circulation. Especially, the overpotential of the MnO2 electrode is the highest one in the first cycle, and increases dramatically in the subsequent cycles because of its inferior OER catalytic activity. Moreover, although the NiCo-LDH cathode displays much lower charge overpotential at the first 30 cycles attributed to high OER catalytic activity, Li2O2 and byproducts accumulated on the NiCo-LDH cathode surface during cycling bring about the passivation of the active sites, resulting in the rapid increase of charging overpotential. Nevertheless, the overpotential of the hybrid catalyst electrode increases slowly in the first cycles, and does not change significantly from the 20th to 140th cycles, proving that the robust NiCo-LDH/MnO2 nanocages have stable catalytic activity (c). It is worth noting that the terminal voltage dropping below 2 V originates from the consumption of the lithium anode and electrolyte instead of the deactivation of NiCo LDH/MnO2 catalysts. As depicted in Figure S12, the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode can still operate normally after reassembly, indicating the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode is effective to improve ORR/OER reaction kinetics and thus extend the cycling life. Furthermore, we carried out cycling measurements under a limited capacity of 1000 mA h g–1. As shown in Figure S13a–c, the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 catalyst shows significant advantages of ameliorating overpotential and improving cycling stability of LOBs compared with the single component. Therefore, NiCo LDH/MnO2-based cells can operate very stably for at least 130 cycles during cycling. In contrast, NiCo LDH/MnO2-based batteries can only maintain 46 and 29 cycles, respectively (Figure S13d).

elements.content: To explore the catalytic mechanism of the electrode catalysts, the morphology and composition of the cathodes after discharge and charge process are further characterized by SEM, XRD, Fourier transform infrared (FTIR), and XPS. As shown in a,b, the loosely wormlike Li2O2 with an irregular arrangement of sheets is uniformly grown on the surface of the NiCo-LDH electrode after discharge. The morphology of Li2O2 can not only provide the open channels beneficial to the oxygen and ion diffusion, but also increase the contact area of the Li2O2/electrolyte interface, making Li2O2 easy to be decomposed and reducing the charging overpotential. For the MnO2 electrode, it can be observed that large disk-like Li2O2 is formed by closely assembled Li2O2 nanosheets (c,d). According to previous reports, the disk-like Li2O2 formation process can be described as follows, some Li2O2 nanoflakes grow on the MnO2 electrode surface during discharge at first, and then a large number of nanoflakes are connected together to form this disk-like Li2O2 with the increasing of Li2O2 density. The large disk-like Li2O2 stacked on the MnO2 electrode with a diameter of about 5 μm, resulting in slow electron and ionic transport performance, making it more difficult for the catalytic decomposition of Li2O2 and resulting in a higher overpotential. On the contrary, the size of Li2O2 on the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 electrode decreases to 1 μm with a typical toroidal structure, as shown in e,f. Interestingly, unlike previously reported toroidal Li2O2-stacked thin plate by a layer-by-layer mechanism, the porous toroidal Li2O2 is also made up of nanoflakes with a thickness of several nanometers. This unique structure displays the advantage of a large specific surface area and close contact with the electrode surface, which makes it easier to implement the delithiation process compared with bulk Li2O2. As expected, there are no obvious residual Li2O2 on the three electrodes maintaining the hollow structure for NiCo-LDH/MnO2 after charge, indicating their good recovery capability and structural stability (Figure S15).
elements.clean_text:
Analysis of the Cathode Electrodes after Discharge and Charge

To explore the catalytic mechanism of the electrode catalysts, the morphology and composition of the cathodes after discharge and charge process are further characterized by SEM, XRD, Fourier transform infrared (FTIR), and XPS. As shown in a,b, the loosely wormlike Li2O2 with an irregular arrangement of sheets is uniformly grown on the surface of the NiCo-LDH electrode after discharge. The morphology of Li2O2 can not only provide the open channels beneficial to the oxygen and ion diffusion, but also increase the contact area of the Li2O2/electrolyte interface, making Li2O2 easy to be decomposed and reducing the charging overpotential. For the MnO2 electrode, it can be observed that large disk-like Li2O2 is formed by closely assembled Li2O2 nanosheets (c,d). According to previous reports, the disk-like Li2O2 formation process can be described as follows, some Li2O2 nanoflakes grow on the MnO2 electrode surface during discharge at first, and then a large number of nanoflakes are connected together to form this disk-like Li2O2 with the increasing of Li2O2 density. The large disk-like Li2O2 stacked on the MnO2 electrode with a diameter of about 5 μm, resulting in slow electron and ionic transport performance, making it more difficult for the catalytic decomposition of Li2O2 and resulting in a higher overpotential. On the contrary, the size of Li2O2 on the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 electrode decreases to 1 μm with a typical toroidal structure, as shown in e,f. Interestingly, unlike previously reported toroidal Li2O2-stacked thin plate by a layer-by-layer mechanism, the porous toroidal Li2O2 is also made up of nanoflakes with a thickness of several nanometers. This unique structure displays the advantage of a large specific surface area and close contact with the electrode surface, which makes it easier to implement the delithiation process compared with bulk Li2O2. As expected, there are no obvious residual Li2O2 on the three electrodes maintaining the hollow structure for NiCo-LDH/MnO2 after charge, indicating their good recovery capability and structural stability (Figure S15).

elements.content: The reversibility of Li2O2 formation and decomposition has been verified by comparing three fully discharged and recharged cathodes using ex situ XRD techniques (a). As for fully discharged cathodes, there are obvious diffraction peaks at 32.7, 34.8, and 58.6° corresponding to the crystal planes of Li2O2 (JCPDS card no. 73-1640), indicating that Li2O2 is the main discharge product. However, only the MnO2 electrode still has a weak bump at 32.7° after the subsequent charge process, demonstrating that Li2O2 could not be completely decomposed for the MnO2 electrode during charging, which leads to the accumulation of Li2O2 on the electrode surface. Thus, the large overpotential and poor cycling performance are observed. In contrast, the characteristic peaks of Li2O2 for the other two electrodes disappear completely, meaning that the discharge and charge capacities are mainly contributed by the reversible formation and decomposition of Li2O2. It is worth noting that the crystalline state of Li2O2 formed by the three electrodes is different. The sharp and narrow diffraction peaks of Li2O2 on the NiCo-LDH electrode illustrate that it has the best crystallinity, while the peak intensity of Li2O2 is lower and broader after NiCo-LDH is combined with MnO2, suggesting that Li2O2 is transformed from highly crystalline to low crystalline. Then, the formation of poor-crystalline state Li2O2 is favorable for the decomposition of Li2O2 and reducing the charge voltage gap.

elements.content: To identify the side products in the process of charge and discharge, the FTIR technique is employed to detect the three electrodes at the 30th cycle, as shown in b. As for the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode, there are evident peaks around 500 to 615 cm–1 for the discharged electrode samples only, indicating that Li2O2 as the main discharge product can form and decompose reversibly. Moreover, the peaks at 865, 1440, and 1485 cm–1 represent the existence of Li2CO3. Generally, Li2CO3 is mainly derived from the decomposition of organic electrolytes and the oxidation of carbon. Compared with the other two electrodes, the weakest intensity of Li2CO3 appears in the FTIR spectrum of the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 discharged electrode, indicating the content of lithium carbonate is the least. Thereafter, it is almost decomposed completely after charge. Furthermore, the characteristic absorption peaks of parasites HCOOLi and CH3COOLi are also observed. For the MnO2 electrode, it is shown that a large amount of side products and residual Li2O2 are generated after the 30th cycle, causing the shortest cycle life. Because the incompletely decomposed side products accumulate on the cathode gradually during the cycling, the passivation layer covered on the cathode surface may greatly inhibit the decomposition of Li2O2. Consequently, it results in an increase of polarization, a reduction of the battery round-trip energy efficiency, and the gradual death of the battery. The three discharged cathodes after the 30th cycle are analyzed by ex situ XPS to further verify Li2O2 and Li2CO3, as presented in Figure S16. As shown in c,d, the evolution of the Li 1s and C 1s peaks in the XPS spectra suggests the formation and full decomposition of the main discharge product, Li2O2, with the residual byproduct, Li2CO3, for the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode. However, for NiCo-LDH and MnO2 electrodes, Li2O2 residues were formed after charge, and a large proportion of Li2CO3 was formed during the charge and discharge process especially for the MnO2 electrode, according to the FTIR results.

elements.content: The electrodes are investigatedusing the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) technique further, and the results are presented as Nyquist plots. The semicircle at high frequencies controlled by the charge transfer process (R ct) represents the resistance of electrode materials. As seen in f and S17, the minimum interface impedance of the initial NiCo-LDH/MnO2 electrode indicates that the charge transfer ability is enhanced. The charge transfer resistance of three electrodes significantly increases after the first discharge because the formation of insulating Li2O2 on the surface of electrodes may reduce the electronic conductivity. During the subsequent recharge, the impedance of the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 electrode can almost recover to its initial state. The impedance of the NiCo-LDH and MnO2 electrodes after one cycle increases to a different degree because the byproducts cannot completely decompose.

elements.content: The different oxygen reduction mechanisms of Li2O2 can be inferred from the different morphologies of Li2O2 formed on different electrodes. At first, O2 captures e– and bonds with solvated Li+ to form a lithium superoxide (LiO2) by one-electron reduction reaction (O2 + e– + Li+ → LiO2). In the following reaction process, whether LiO2 intermediates are adsorbed on the cathode surface or dissolved into the electrolyte are determined by the different adsorption free energies of LiO2 intermediates. Therefore, the ORR mechanism can be divided into two patterns, that is, the surface-absorption pathway and the solution-mediated pathway. For the NiCo-LDH-based electrode, because of high absorption energy of NiCo-LDH to LiO2 intermediates and low LiO2 solubility in the electrolyte, LiO2 intermediates are preferentially adsorbed on the cathode. The adsorbed LiO2* species (“*” refers to the adsorbed species and “sol” represents the dissolved species) are formed on the surface of the NiCo-LDH electrode and then undergo a second reduction or disproportionation reaction (LiO2 * + e– + Li+ → Li2O2 * or 2LiO2 * → Li2O2 * + O2) in the surface-adsorption growth procedure. Subsequently, Li2O2 ultrathin sheets grow on the electrode surface with the formed Li2O2 as nucleation sites, leading to a low charge overpotential. For the MnO2 based electrode, O2 – is absorbed on the surface of MnO2 first owing to the oxygen vacancy and the K+ existing in the interlayer space. Then, the LiO2 species formed a multimer in the electrolyte because of the weaker surface-binding energy between the superoxide species and MnO2 after the generation of LiO2. Afterward, Li2O2 is induced to produce on the surface of the cathode through a solution-mediated route (2LiO2 sol → Li2O2 + O2). Thereafter, the heterogeneous nucleation and growth process occurs on the cathode surface, resulting in the formation of disk-like Li2O2 assembled by nanosheets. For the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode, the characteristic morphology of both the surface-adsorption process and the solution-mediated process of Li2O2 coexist because of the synergistic effects of different adsorption behaviors of NiCo-LDH and MnO2. NiCo-LDH acts as the initial growth site of Li2O2 seeds because of a high absorption energy to LiO2 * for subsequent Li2O2 growth, while the MnO2 nanosheets provide a large amount of dissolved LiO2sol. At first, LiO2 * and LiO2sol are formed on the NiCo-LDH and MnO2 surfaces, respectively. In the nucleation stage, LiO2 */LiO2sol is mainly adsorbed on the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 surface and rapidly transformed into Li2O2 seeds through an electrochemical reduction or a disproportionation reaction. A small amount of LiO2sol transforms into Li2O2 deposited on the surface as seeds through solution growth. After the nucleation process, abundant LiO2sol in the electrolyte become Li2O2 through disproportionation. When the Li2O2 cluster reaches a supersaturated state, solid Li2O2 deposits on Li2O2 seeds forming toroid-shaped Li2O2 with tightly aligned nanosheets.

The adsorbed LiO2* species ("*" refers to the adsorbed species and "sol" represents the dissolved species) are formed on the surface of the NiCo-LDH electrode and then undergo a second reduction or disproportionation reaction (LiO2 * + e- + Li+ → Li2O2 * or 2LiO2 * → Li2O2 * + O2) in the surface-adsorption growth procedure. Subsequently, Li2O2 ultrathin sheets grow on the electrode surface with the formed Li2O2 as nucleation sites, leading to a low charge overpotential. For the MnO2 based electrode, O2 - is absorbed on the surface of MnO2 first owing to the oxygen vacancy and the K+ existing in the interlayer space. Then, the LiO2 species formed a multimer in the electrolyte because of the weaker surface-binding energy between the superoxide species and MnO2 after the generation of LiO2. Afterward, Li2O2 is induced to produce on the surface of the cathode through a solution-mediated route (2LiO2 sol → Li2O2 + O2). Thereafter, the heterogeneous nucleation and growth process occurs on the cathode surface, resulting in the formation of disk-like Li2O2 assembled by nanosheets. For the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode, the characteristic morphology of both the surface-adsorption process and the solution-mediated process of Li2O2 coexist because of the synergistic effects of different adsorption behaviors of NiCo-LDH and MnO2. NiCo-LDH acts as the initial growth site of Li2O2 seeds because of a high absorption energy to LiO2 * for subsequent Li2O2 growth, while the MnO2 nanosheets provide a large amount of dissolved LiO2sol. At first, LiO2 * and LiO2sol are formed on the NiCo-LDH and MnO2 surfaces, respectively. In the nucleation stage, LiO2 */LiO2sol is mainly adsorbed on the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 surface and rapidly transformed into Li2O2 seeds through an electrochemical reduction or a disproportionation reaction. A small amount of LiO2sol transforms into Li2O2 deposited on the surface as seeds through solution growth. After the nucleation process, abundant LiO2sol in the electrolyte become Li2O2 through disproportionation. When the Li2O2 cluster reaches a supersaturated state, solid Li2O2 deposits on Li2O2 seeds forming toroid-shaped Li2O2 with tightly aligned nanosheets.

cln_elements.content:
The commercial application of lithium–oxygen (Li–O2) batteries has been seriously hindered by their large overpotential and inferior cycling performance caused by the insoluble and insulated traits of the discharge product, Li2O2. Herein, hierarchical hollow NiCo-LDH/MnO2 hybrid nanostructures derived from metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are successfully constructed as cathodes for Li–O2 batteries to fundamentally improve the decomposition kinetics of Li2O2. The hollow NiCo-LDH/MnO2 nanostructures assembled by hollow NiCo-LDH and MnO2 nanosheets possess a highly special surface area, abundant open active sites, and a fast diffusion path for Li+ and oxygen species. As expected, accelerated sluggish oxygen reduction reaction/oxygen evolution reaction kinetics and reduced charge/discharge overpotentials can be obtained. The toroidal Li2O2 assembled by nanoflakes formed on the surface of the cathode can be conducive to form a low-impedance Li2O2/cathode contact interface to achieve the reversible formation and decomposition of Li2O2. The Li–O2 battery based on the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode shows a high charge/discharge specific capacity of 13,380 mA h g–1 at 100 mA g–1 and a continuous cycling stability for 162 cycles at a fixed capacity of 500 mAh g–1 as well as a low overpotential of 0.63 V. Moreover, the application of MOF-derived porous hierarchical nanostructures expands the selection range of electrocatalysts and offers a new idea of structure design for Li–O2 batteries.

Herein, an efficient strategy to construct novel hollow NiCo-LDH/MnO2 hierarchical nanostructures as cathodes for LOBs is developed. Specifically, the hollow NiCo-LDH nanocages are formed by ZIF-67 as the self-template, and then the ultrathin MnO2 nanosheets are grown on the NiCo-LDH nanocages. The LOBs based on NiCo-LDH/MnO2 nanostructures display a lower overpotential (0.63 V) and a higher capacity of 13380 mA h g –1 at a current density of 100mA g–1 as well as excellent cycling stability (163 cycles at 100 mA g –1) because of the synergistic effect of NiCo-LDH and MnO2. NiCo-LDH/MnO2 nanocages modulate the Li2O2 growth mechanisms of the surface-adsorption pathway and the solvation-mediated pathway to induce the formation of unique porous toroidal Li2O2 assembled by densified nanoflakes with poor crystallinity. This unique structure offers a large specific surface area and accelerates the complete decomposition of Li2O2 during the OER.

The crystal structures of the NiCo-LDH, MnO2, and NiCo-LDH/MnO2 samples are determined using the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns. From a, the broad diffraction peaks at 11.7, 23.7, 34.2, and 60.1° can be assigned to the (003), (006), (012), and (110) planes indexed to the Ni­(OH)2 phase (JCPDS no. 38-0715). In addition, the diffraction peaks located at 12.5, 25.0, 36.8, and 65.5° are attributed to the (003), (006), (101), and (110) planes of δ-MnO2 (JCPDS no. 86-0666), respectively. The composition and chemical bonding states of the hollow NiCo-LDH/MnO2 nanocages are further confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The survey scan of the XPS spectrum (Figure S3) shows the presence of the peaks of Co 2p, Ni 2p, Mn 2p, Mn 3s, Mn 3p, and O1s. For the Co 2p spectrum, the peaks at 795.9 and 780.7 eV correspond to 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of Co2+, and the peaks at 790.4 and 774.5 eV are correspond to Co3+. The high-resolution XPS Ni 2p spectrum (c) also can be fitted into four peaks, which correspond to the Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 of Ni2+ (855.5 and 873.1 eV) as well as the satellite feature (874.3 and 856.6 eV). In the Mn 2p spectrum, the Mn 2p3/2 (642.1 eV) and Mn 2p1/2 (653.8 eV) peaks can be accounted for Mn4+. Additionally, the O 1s peak in e can be deconvoluted into two peaks. The peak at 529.8 eV is assigned to the Mn–O functional group and the distinct peak at 531.1 eV is associated with the hydroxide groups, suggesting the formation of NiCo-LDH. According to the elemental contents measured by XPS (Table S2), the weight ratio of MnO2 is about 36% in the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 composite.

As shown in f and S5, the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms of NiCo-LDH and NiCo-LDH/MnO2 display the characteristics of the type-IV isotherm, indicating that the presence of abundant mesopores in the samples. The pore size distribution of the NiCo-LDH and NiCo-LDH/MnO2 samples is found to be mainly on the mesoscale. It shows a large specific surface area of NiCo-LDH/MnO2 (217.1 m2 g–1) calculated using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method from isotherms, similar to that of NiCo-LDH (218.9 m2 g–1). This porous structure is conducive to gas diffusion and ion transportation as well as the accelerating battery reaction rate.

Electrochemical Performance of Electrocatalysts in LOBs

The electrochemical performances of NiCo-LDH, MnO2, and NiCo-LDH/MnO2 electrodes are comparatively investigated. The electrochemical measurement results are calculated on the basis of the total weight of cathode catalysts (NiCo-LDH or MnO2 or NiCo-LDH/MnO2) and Super P. a displays the cyclic voltammogram (CV) plots of the three electrodes at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s–1 within the voltage range of 2.0–4.5 V. The CV plot of the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 hybrid catalyst electrode exhibits a single cathodic peak at around 2.44 V, which is ascribed to the oxygen reduction (O2 + 2Li+ + 2e– → Li2O2), while the two oxidation peaks located at 3.41 and 4.36 V are ascribed to the stepwise delithiation and the bulk oxidation process of Li2O2 (Li2O2 → O2 + 2Li+ + 2e–), which are higher than those of NiCo-LDH and MnO2 monophase catalyst electrodes. Compared with two monophase catalysts, the hybrid catalyst delivers a higher ORR onset potential and a lower OER onset potential, revealing the higher ORR and OER catalytic activity. In addition, the higher ORR and OER peak current and integrated area indicate that there are more Li2O2 generation/decomposition.

b depicts three galvanostatic discharge/charge profiles in the voltage window of 2.0–4.5 V versus Li+/Li with NiCo-LDH, MnO2, and NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathodes at a current density of 100 mA g–1. By comparison, the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode exhibits a high discharge capacity (13380 mA h g–1) with the reversible ORR/OER process, while the NiCo-LDH and MnO2 electrodes can only exhibit capacities of 5380 and 9360 mA h g–1. It should be noted that the discharge capacities are mainly contributed by ORR (Figure S6). In addition, the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 catalyst also plays a significant role in reducing the polarization of LOBs. The NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode exhibits a flat discharge plateau of 2.66 V and a charge midcapacity potential (defined as the voltage at half capacity) of 4.0 V with the lower polarization (approximately 0.30 and 1.04 V during discharge and charge). However, the overpotential of NiCo-LDH and MnO2 is 1.47 and 1.59 V, respectively, marking the generation and decomposition of Li2O2 more difficult, and the side reactions are exacerbated during the discharge/charge process for monophase catalyst cathodes. Therefore, NiCo-LDH/MnO2 with enhanced OER and ORR catalytic activity can effectively improve the electrochemical performance of LOBs.

c shows the discharge/charge curves of NiCo-LDH, MnO2, and NiCo-LDH/MnO2 electrodes at various current densities. The ORR/OER overpotentials of these three electrodes increase with the increasing of current density to different degrees. The increment of the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 electrode is the smallest. The overpotential of NiCo-LDH/MnO2 is 1.44 V at 400 mA g–1 and 1.60 V at 800 mA g–1. Moreover, the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 electrode still maintains a high capacity of about 9099 mA h g–1 at a current density of 800 mA g–1, indicating its good capacity retention performance. However, when the current density recovers to 200 mA g–1, an approximate original state can still be restored. Furthermore, the capacity retention of the battery with the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 electrode is also improved (e). For instance, the discharge capacity retention of NiCo-LDH/MnO2 is 78.8% at 400 mA g–1, while the NiCo-LDH and MnO2 sample reserves only 72.9 and 66.3%. When the current density increases to 800 mA g–1, the capacity retention of the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 electrode maintains at 68.0%, and the values of the NiCo-LDH and MnO2 electrodes, respectively, decrease to 52.3 and 38.8% yet. The improvements of the capacity and rate capability should be ascribed to the synergistic effect of NiCo-LDH and MnO2.

The cycling stability of LOBs based on three cathodes is measured at a current density of 100 mA g–1 and a cutoff capacity of 500 mA h g–1 (). The NiCo-LDH/MnO2-based electrode battery displays a better cycling performance than others. The NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode shows a reduced overpotential (0.21/0.42 V) for both discharge and charge in comparison with NiCo-LDH (0.38 V/0.46 V) and MnO2 (0.29 V/0.76 V) cathodes at the first cycle (a), demonstrating that the synergistic effect of NiCo-LDH and MnO2 can enhance the formation and decomposition kinetics of Li2O2. As illustrated in d, the LOB based on the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode exhibits a longer cycle life of 162 cycles before the terminal voltage drops below 2 V, while NiCo-LDH and MnO2 only work for 98 cycles and 31 cycles, respectively. The terminal discharge/charge voltages maintain relatively stable states up to 130 cycles for the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 electrode. The charge overpotentials of NiCo-LDH (c) and MnO2 (Figure S8) electrodes increase continuously to 4.5 V during circulation. Especially, the overpotential of the MnO2 electrode is the highest one in the first cycle, and increases dramatically in the subsequent cycles because of its inferior OER catalytic activity. Moreover, although the NiCo-LDH cathode displays much lower charge overpotential at the first 30 cycles attributed to high OER catalytic activity, Li2O2 and byproducts accumulated on the NiCo-LDH cathode surface during cycling bring about the passivation of the active sites, resulting in the rapid increase of charging overpotential. Nevertheless, the overpotential of the hybrid catalyst electrode increases slowly in the first cycles, and does not change significantly from the 20th to 140th cycles, proving that the robust NiCo-LDH/MnO2 nanocages have stable catalytic activity (c). It is worth noting that the terminal voltage dropping below 2 V originates from the consumption of the lithium anode and electrolyte instead of the deactivation of NiCo LDH/MnO2 catalysts. As depicted in Figure S12, the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode can still operate normally after reassembly, indicating the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode is effective to improve ORR/OER reaction kinetics and thus extend the cycling life. Furthermore, we carried out cycling measurements under a limited capacity of 1000 mA h g–1. As shown in Figure S13a–c, the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 catalyst shows significant advantages of ameliorating overpotential and improving cycling stability of LOBs compared with the single component. Therefore, NiCo LDH/MnO2-based cells can operate very stably for at least 130 cycles during cycling. In contrast, NiCo LDH/MnO2-based batteries can only maintain 46 and 29 cycles, respectively (Figure S13d).

The reversibility of Li2O2 formation and decomposition has been verified by comparing three fully discharged and recharged cathodes using ex situ XRD techniques (a). As for fully discharged cathodes, there are obvious diffraction peaks at 32.7, 34.8, and 58.6° corresponding to the crystal planes of Li2O2 (JCPDS card no. 73-1640), indicating that Li2O2 is the main discharge product. However, only the MnO2 electrode still has a weak bump at 32.7° after the subsequent charge process, demonstrating that Li2O2 could not be completely decomposed for the MnO2 electrode during charging, which leads to the accumulation of Li2O2 on the electrode surface. Thus, the large overpotential and poor cycling performance are observed. In contrast, the characteristic peaks of Li2O2 for the other two electrodes disappear completely, meaning that the discharge and charge capacities are mainly contributed by the reversible formation and decomposition of Li2O2. It is worth noting that the crystalline state of Li2O2 formed by the three electrodes is different. The sharp and narrow diffraction peaks of Li2O2 on the NiCo-LDH electrode illustrate that it has the best crystallinity, while the peak intensity of Li2O2 is lower and broader after NiCo-LDH is combined with MnO2, suggesting that Li2O2 is transformed from highly crystalline to low crystalline. Then, the formation of poor-crystalline state Li2O2 is favorable for the decomposition of Li2O2 and reducing the charge voltage gap.

Conclusions

In summary, hierarchical hollow NiCo-LDH/MnO2 nanostructures derived from MOFs using a facile method were rationally designed for LOBs. The hollow NiCo-LDH/MnO2 hierarchical nanostructures exhibit excellent electrocatalytic performance with a highly charge/discharge specific capacity of 13,380 mA h g–1 at 100 mA g–1, a long-term cycling stability for 162 cycles at a cutoff capacity of 500 mAh g–1, and a low overpotential of 0.63 V in the first cycle. The hollow NiCo-LDH/MnO2 nanostructures possess highly special surface areas, abundant open active sites, and short diffusion paths for Li+ and oxygen, and show advantages of enhancing catalytic activity for ORR and OER, as well as reducing charge/discharge overpotential. Furthermore, for the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathodes, the porous toroidal Li2O2 are made up of nanosheets formed during the discharge process resulting from the synergistic effect of NiCo-LDH and MnO2. The toroidal Li2O2 assembled by fine nanoflakes formed on the surface of cathode can be conducive to form a low-impedance Li2O2/cathode contact interface to achieve the reversible formation and decomposition of Li2O2. This unique porous structure not only brings large specific capacity, but also reduces polarization and further improves battery performance. Moreover, the application of MOF derivatives expands the selection range of electrocatalysts and offers a new idea of structure design for LOBs.

The cycling stability of LOBs based on three cathodes is measured at a current density of 100 mA g-1 and a cutoff capacity of 500 mA h g-1 (). The NiCo-LDH/MnO2-based electrode battery displays a better cycling performance than others. The NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode shows a reduced overpotential (0.21/0.42 V) for both discharge and charge in comparison with NiCo-LDH (0.38 V/0.46 V) and MnO2 (0.29 V/0.76 V) cathodes at the first cycle (a), demonstrating that the synergistic effect of NiCo-LDH and MnO2 can enhance the formation and decomposition kinetics of Li2O2. As illustrated in d, the LOB based on the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode exhibits a longer cycle life of 162 cycles before the terminal voltage drops below 2 V, while NiCo-LDH and MnO2 only work for 98 cycles and 31 cycles, respectively. The terminal discharge/charge voltages maintain relatively stable states up to 130 cycles for the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 electrode. The charge overpotentials of NiCo-LDH (c) and MnO2 (Figure S8) electrodes increase continuously to 4.5 V during circulation. Especially, the overpotential of the MnO2 electrode is the highest one in the first cycle, and increases dramatically in the subsequent cycles because of its inferior OER catalytic activity. Moreover, although the NiCo-LDH cathode displays much lower charge overpotential at the first 30 cycles attributed to high OER catalytic activity, Li2O2 and byproducts accumulated on the NiCo-LDH cathode surface during cycling bring about the passivation of the active sites, resulting in the rapid increase of charging overpotential. Nevertheless, the overpotential of the hybrid catalyst electrode increases slowly in the first cycles, and does not change significantly from the 20th to 140th cycles, proving that the robust NiCo-LDH/MnO2 nanocages have stable catalytic activity (c). It is worth noting that the terminal voltage dropping below 2 V originates from the consumption of the lithium anode and electrolyte instead of the deactivation of NiCo LDH/MnO2 catalysts. As depicted in Figure S12, the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode can still operate normally after reassembly, indicating the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode is effective to improve ORR/OER reaction kinetics and thus extend the cycling life. Furthermore, we carried out cycling measurements under a limited capacity of 1000 mA h g-1. As shown in Figure S13a-c, the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 catalyst shows significant advantages of ameliorating overpotential and improving cycling stability of LOBs compared with the single component. Therefore, NiCo LDH/MnO2-based cells can operate very stably for at least 130 cycles during cycling. In contrast, NiCo LDH/MnO2-based batteries can only maintain 46 and 29 cycles, respectively (Figure S13d).

The reversibility of Li2O2 formation and decomposition has been verified by comparing three fully discharged and recharged cathodes using ex situ XRD techniques (a). As for fully discharged cathodes, there are obvious diffraction peaks at 32.7, 34.8, and 58.6° corresponding to the crystal planes of Li2O2 (JCPDS card no. 73-1640), indicating that Li2O2 is the main discharge product. However, only the MnO2 electrode still has a weak bump at 32.7° after the subsequent charge process, demonstrating that Li2O2 could not be completely decomposed for the MnO2 electrode during charging, which leads to the accumulation of Li2O2 on the electrode surface. Thus, the large overpotential and poor cycling performance are observed. In contrast, the characteristic peaks of Li2O2 for the other two electrodes disappear completely, meaning that the discharge and charge capacities are mainly contributed by the reversible formation and decomposition of Li2O2. It is worth noting that the crystalline state of Li2O2 formed by the three electrodes is different. The sharp and narrow diffraction peaks of Li2O2 on the NiCo-LDH electrode illustrate that it has the best crystallinity, while the peak intensity of Li2O2 is lower and broader after NiCo-LDH is combined with MnO2, suggesting that Li2O2 is transformed from highly crystalline to low crystalline. Then, the formation of poor-crystalline state Li2O2 is favorable for the decomposition of Li2O2 and reducing the charge voltage gap.

Conclusions

In summary, hierarchical hollow NiCo-LDH/MnO2 nanostructures derived from MOFs using a facile method were rationally designed for LOBs. The hollow NiCo-LDH/MnO2 hierarchical nanostructures exhibit excellent electrocatalytic performance with a highly charge/discharge specific capacity of 13,380 mA h g-1 at 100 mA g-1, a long-term cycling stability for 162 cycles at a cutoff capacity of 500 mAh g-1, and a low overpotential of 0.63 V in the first cycle. The hollow NiCo-LDH/MnO2 nanostructures possess highly special surface areas, abundant open active sites, and short diffusion paths for Li+ and oxygen, and show advantages of enhancing catalytic activity for ORR and OER, as well as reducing charge/discharge overpotential. Furthermore, for the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathodes, the porous toroidal Li2O2 are made up of nanosheets formed during the discharge process resulting from the synergistic effect of NiCo-LDH and MnO2. The toroidal Li2O2 assembled by fine nanoflakes formed on the surface of cathode can be conducive to form a low-impedance Li2O2/cathode contact interface to achieve the reversible formation and decomposition of Li2O2. This unique porous structure not only brings large specific capacity, but also reduces polarization and further improves battery performance. Moreover, the application of MOF derivatives expands the selection range of electrocatalysts and offers a new idea of structure design for LOBs.
